DeregistrationReasonOtherText: Facility has been sold to another company and no longer operated by ExxonMobil.

Site will provide training, share information regarding hazards identified during Process Hazard Analysis, and coordinate operating practices to simplify operations and ensure safety.

Incident Investigation

The Site has had no incidents, to date, that would require an accident investigation. However, there is a system in place to investigate any incident that could result, or could reasonably result in, a fire/explosion, flammable gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury. The goal of an investigation is to determine the facts and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident. The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards these results to management for resolution. Corrective actions potentially taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations will be tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding or recommendation will be documented, and the investigation results reviewed with all employees and contractors who could be affected by the findings. Any incident investigation reports will be retained for five years and will be reviewed during future PHAs and PHA revalidations.

Compliance Audits

To help ensure the accident prevention program is functioning properly, the Site conducts an audit every 3 years to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program are being implemented. Compliance audits are to be conducted at least every three years. A representative from the operating contractor, XTO field operations, and a third party participate as audit team members. The audit team develops findings that are forwarded to management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit repo

ty Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). This coordination includes periodic meetings, which include local emergency response officials, and local government officials. The Site contacts local emergency responders annually with regard to the hazards of regulated substances at the Site. Annual Tier II Chemical Inventory filings are provided to the LEPC which detail the hazardous chemicals at the Site.

XTO has implemented an Emergency Response Plan (ERP), elements of which overlap those of the RMP.  The ERP provides the following information:
¿	Procedures for informing the public and offsite emergency response officials of a release. 
-	The individuals and groups contacted, the means by which they will be contacted, the time frame for notification, and the information that will be provided is included in the ERP.
¿	The proper procedures for first aid and medical treatment for employees, first responders, and members of the public exposed to a release.
-	Safety precautions for injured parties and detailed information for medical professionals
-	Information regarding who is likely responsible for providing appropriate treatment (e.g., an employee, an employee with specialized training, or a medical professional).
¿	Procedures for emergency response in the event of a release of a regulated substance, including descriptions of actions to be taken by employees and other individuals onsite over the course of the release event such as:
-	Activation of alarm systems and interpretation of signals
-	Safe evacuation, assembly, and return
-	Selection of response strategies and incident command structure
-	Use of response equipment and other release mitigation activities
-	Post-release equipment and personnel cleanup and decontamination. 

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

No changes are currently proposed for the Site.  In the event a change is identified that would improve safety, that change will be implemented upon management approval and directive. The

intenance, (3) a guideline for safe removal of hazardous substances before process piping or equipment is opened, (4) a permit and guideline to control spark-producing activities, such as hot work, and (5) a permit and guideline to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space. These, and other guidelines, along with training of affected personnel, form a system to help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

In the five years previous to the submission of this report, the Site has had an excellent record of preventing accidental releases, with no RMP-reportable incidents.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Site maintains a written emergency response program, which is in place to protect worker and public safety, as well as to protect the environment. The program consists of procedures for contacting responders for mitigation of a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released. The procedures address aspects of emergency response by outside experts, and include proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and post-incident cleanup and any decontamination requirements. Employees receive appropriate training in procedures necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties which includes contacting trained responders. The emergency response program is updated when necessary based on modifications made to Site processes or other facilities within the Site. The emergency response program changes are administered through the Management of Change process, which includes informing and/or training affected personnel of the changes.
The overall emergency response program for the Site is coordinated with the Harrison Coun

nd vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition. The basic aspects of this program include: (1) conducting training, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing inspections and tests, (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures. In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process.
Employees receive training on (1) an overview of the process, (2) safety and health hazards, (3) applicable maintenance procedures, (4) emergency response plans, and (5) applicable safe work practices to help ensure that they can perform their jobs in a safe manner. Written procedures help ensure that work is performed in a consistent manner and provide a basis for training. Inspections and tests are performed to help ensure that equipment functions as intended and to verify that equipment is within acceptable limits, such as adequate wall thickness for pressure vessels. If a deficiency is identified, employees will correct the deficiency before placing the equipment back into service, or a management of change team will review the use of the equipment and determine what actions are necessary to ensure the safe operation of the equipment. 
Another integral part of the mechanical integrity program is quality assurance. The Site incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs by the supplier. The supplier is responsible for ensuring that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper materials and spare parts are used when repairs are made. 
Safe Work Practices

The Site has implemented safe work practices to help ensure worker and process safety. Examples of these include: (1) control of the entry/presence/exit of support personnel by use of locks held by qualified contractors and employees, (2) lockout/tagout guidelines to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing ma

(1) contain/control a release, (2) quickly detect a release, and (3) reduce the consequences of a release. The following types of safety features are used in the covered processes:
¿	Release containment and control
-	Valves to permit isolation of the operations (manual and automated)
-	Automated bypasses and manual shutoffs for specific process parameters.
-	Pressure relief valves are properly sized and tested every 3 years.  Any such valve that fails a test will be replaced or repaired and tested annually until reliability is ensured.
-	Baseline ultrasonic testing thickness testing of the bullet tank will be performed prior to startup.
-	Automated shutdown systems for specific process parameters.
-	Atmospheric relief devices.
¿	Release mitigation
-	Fire extinguishing devices. 
-	The local fire department has been notified about the potential hazards of the Site and has been provided the emergency response plan.

Training

To complement the written procedures for process operations, XTO has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating a process. New employees receive basic training in refrigeration Site operations if they are not already familiar with such operations. After successfully completing this training, XTO management verifies that the XTO personnel are competent to operate the equipment. After operators demonstrate having adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they can work independently. In addition, all periodically receive refresher training on the operating procedures to ensure their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level. Refresher training is conducted at least every three years. All of this training is documented for each operator, including the means used to verify that the operator understood the training.

Maintenance

The Site has well-established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief a

y features applicable to prevention of accidental releases of regulated substances in the location.

Process Safety Analysis

The Site has a program to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled. Within this program, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards.
The hazard analysis is conducted by XTO personnel with maintenance experience as well as engineering expertise of this type of facility. XTO personnel analyze and evaluate hazards of the processes, as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures, and make suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when such measures are determined to be necessary.

Hazard analysis findings are forwarded to management for resolution.  Implementation of mitigation options in response to findings is based on relative risk ranking by XTO personnel.  The ranking helps ensure that potential accident scenarios assigned the highest risk receive immediate attention.  All approved mitigation options in response to XTO personnel's hazard analysis findings are tracked until completed.  The final solution of each finding is documented and retained.  

To help ensure that the process controls and/or process hazards do not eventually deviate significantly from the original design safety features, the Site periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis results. These periodic reviews are conducted at least every five years and when equipment or operating procedures change, and will be conducted at this frequency until the process is no longer operating. The results and findings from these updates are documented and retained. Once again, the team findings are forwarded to management for consideration, and the final resolution of the findings is documented and retained.
 

Specialized Safety Features

The Site has safety features on many units to help

ENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

XTO maintains a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the Site's processes. These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters and specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information. Employees at the Site are active in the development and maintenance of up-to-date process safety information. Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in material safety data sheets (MSDSs). This information is supplemented by documents that specifically address known concerns. For specific operations areas, the Site has documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters, such as temperature, level, and composition. The Site ensures that each process is maintained within approved limits using process controls and monitoring instruments, trained personnel, and protective instrument systems, such as automated shutdown systems.

The Site also maintains technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment. This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, and electrical rating of equipment. This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and Site changes to ensure that safety features in the process are not compromised. The Site's operational status is inspected during the operator's normal hours. Identified issues are reported to Kinder Morgan, who is responsible for the maintenance of equipment at the Site.

The following Risk Management Plan (RMP) has been produced as required by the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) in Section 112 (r) of the Clean Air Act. 

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES

XTO Energy, Inc. (XTO) has a strong commitment to the protection of workers and the environment.  The North Lansing Site (the Site) has an active safety program covering both employees and contract workers. This program encompasses promotion of safe work practices to prevent personal accidents, and incidents that would adversely affect the community. XTO recognizes their commitment to accident prevention through continuing programs including personnel training. Consideration is also given to safety in the design, installation, and operation of all operating units and modifications to the Site. The safety commitment is also carried forth as evidenced by an aggressive maintenance program. Reasonable controls have been implemented to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. In the unlikely event that a release does occur, arrangements have been made within the local community to provide response and control of any catastrophic releases. Passive mitigation, such as vents, is present at the Site to manage any overpressure conditions that may occur. 

DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The Site is located near the southwestern corner of the intersection of Farm-to-Market (FM) 449 and FM 2208 approximately 7 miles southeast of Harleton, Texas in Harrison County. The Site neither uses nor stores any regulated toxic substance above RMP threshold quantities (40 CFR § 68.130). Inherent with the operation of a gas refrigeration site, the Site processes and stores regulated flammable substances above the threshold quantity. These flammable substances are addressed throughout the RMP, and may include pentane, ethane, propane, and butane, which are all components of the Natural Gas Liquids Product (NGLP).
